name: Aneilema semifoliatum
reference: Trans. Linn. Soc. London, Bot. ser. 2, 4: 498. 1895

name: Chamaeanthus wittianus
reference: Verh. Bot. Vereins Prov. Brandenburg 50: 71 (-72). 1908 [10 Jun 1908]

name: Commelina catharinensis
distribution: Santa Catarina (Brazil South, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Commelina huntii
distribution: Rio de Janeiro (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);São Paulo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.3897/phytokeys.78.11932 this species is named after the British botanist Dr. David R.Hunt, in honor of his extensive contribution to Commelinaceae systematics worldwide, especially for his contributions to Tradescantieae and the Phaeosphaerion group of Commelina

name: Dichorisandra aonae
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.1590/2175-7860202273029 Etymology: 'The specific epithet honors Dr. Lidyanne Yuriko Saleme Aona (Universidade Federal do Recôncavo da Bahia) for her contributions to the taxonomy of Dichorisandra'.

name: Dichorisandra flesheri
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.647.2.6 Etymology: name honours the ecologist Dr. Kevin Michael Flesher, Director of the Reserva Ecológica Michelin (REM), responsible for the conservation, and research management of the area where this new species was discovered.

name: Dichorisandra fluminensis
reference: Arch. Jard. Bot. Rio de Janeiro 15: [7], tab. 1, fig. 4-8, tab. 5. 1957
publication: Arch. Jard. Bot. Rio de Janeiro

name: Dichorisandra forzzae
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.1111/njb.02654 The specific epithet honours the Brazilian botanist Dr Rafaela Campostrini Forzza (Instituto de Pesquisa Jardim Botânico do Rio de Janeiro), for her contributions to the knowledge of the Brazilian flora.

name: Dichorisandra glandulosa
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.1590/2175-7860202273029 Etymology: 'The epithet glandulosa makes reference to this species glandular-pubescent inflorescences, sepals, ovary and capsules'.

name: Dichorisandra leonii
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Dichorisandra nana
distribution: Rio de Janeiro (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Dichorisandra neglecta
reference: Arch. Jard. Bot. Rio de Janeiro 15: 8, tab. 1, fig. 1-3, tab. 4. 1957
publication: Arch. Jard. Bot. Rio de Janeiro

name: Dichorisandra nutabilis
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Dichorisandra odorata
distribution: Rio de Janeiro (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Dichorisandra pulcherrima
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.620.3.2 Etymology: 'The specific epithet pulcherrima, derived from the Latin pulcher, which means beautiful'.

name: Dichorisandra rhizantha
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.538.3.9 Etymology: 'The specific epithet is a reference to the characteristic flowering branches arising directly from the rhizome apparently perforating the sheaths of the leaves on the axillary branches, with leaves absent or with only a few developing later'.

name: Dichorisandra rigidifolia
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.561.1.9 Etymology: name alludes to the rigid aspect of the leaves of the new species when compared to congeners.

name: Dichorisandra rupicola
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Dichorisandra striatula
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Dichorisandra velutina
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Murdannia engelsii
distribution: Mato Grosso (Brazil West-Central, Brazil, Southern America);Mato Grosso do Sul (Brazil West-Central, Brazil, Southern America);Tocantins (Brazil North, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.3897/phytokeys.74.9835 The epithet honors the collector of the holotype, the Brazilian botanist Mathias Erich Engels, Orchidaceae taxonomist and dear friend of the authors.

name: Siderasis albofasciata
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Siderasis almeidae
remarks: doi:10.3897/phytokeys.83.13490 the specific epithet honours Brazilian botanist Rafael Felipe de Almeida

name: Siderasis medusoides
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.3897/phytokeys.83.13490 the epithet alludes to the extremely elongated cincinni, due to their resemblance to the snakes that composed the hair of Medusa, one of the three Gorgon sisters from Greek mythology

name: Siderasis spectabilis
distribution: Rio de Janeiro (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Siderasis zorzanellii
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.3897/phytokeys.83.13490 the specific epithet honours the collector of the type specimens, João Paulo Fernandes Zorzanelli

name: Tradescantia atlantica
distribution: Rio de Janeiro (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);São Paulo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.3897/phytokeys.101.25057 originally published online; redacted and published in print as PhytoKeys 104: 1-97. 2018.

name: Tradescantia chrysophylla
distribution: São Paulo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);Paraná (Brazil South, Brazil, Southern America);Rio de Janeiro (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);Santa Catarina (Brazil South, Brazil, Southern America);

name: Tradescantia fluminensis
reference: Fl. Flumin. 140. 1829 [1825 publ. 7 Sep-28 Nov 1829] ; see also Fl. Flumin. Icon. 3: t. 152. 1831 [1827 publ. 29 Oct 1831].

name: Tradescantia hertweckiae
distribution: Rio de Janeiro (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.3897/phytokeys.101.25057 the specific epithet is named after Dr. Kate Hertweck. Originally published online; redacted and published in print as PhytoKeys 104: 1-97. 2018.

name: Tradescantia insularis
distribution: Santa Catarina (Brazil South, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.458.2.2 The specific epithet refers to Santa Catarina Island, on which the only known population is located.

name: Tradescantia multibracteata
distribution: Rio Grande do Sul (Brazil South, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.308.1.7 the epithet refers to the remarkable high number of bracts in the inflorescence. From Latin multo = many, bractea = bract

name: Tradescantia schwirkowskiana
distribution: Santa Catarina (Brazil South, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: oi:10.11646/phytotaxa.272.1.3 the specific epithet is named after Paulo Schwirkowski, a notorious naturalist and plant collector from São Bento do Sul municipality, who for many years has been contributing to the knowledge of the flora of Santa Catarina

name: Tradescantia serrana
distribution: Santa Catarina (Brazil South, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.312.2.4 the specific epithet refers to the Serra Geral, a highland area in southern Brazil

name: Tradescantia seubertiana
distribution: Santa Catarina (Brazil South, Brazil, Southern America);Paraná (Brazil South, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.265.1.8 this species is named after the prominent German botanist Moritz August Seubert (1818–1878), in appreciation for his extensive contribution to Commelinaceae systematics, especially for his contributions to the knowledge of the Brazilian Commelinaceae

name: Tradescantia umbraculifera
reference: Denkschr. Kaiserl. Akad. Wiss., Wien. Math.-Naturwiss. Kl. 79: 204. 1908
publication: Denkschr. Kaiserl. Akad. Wiss., Wien. Math.-Naturwiss. Kl.
